elements.content: The synthesis and structural characterization of the first iron complex derived from the salen-type thymidine-based ligand 1 is reported; the crystal structure of [FeIII(3‘,5‘-bis(salicylaldiminato)-3‘,5‘-dideoxy-β-d-xylo-thymidine)(SCN)] (Fe1) reveals an unusual coordination polymer arranged as a homochiral array of right-handed helices with four-fold screw symmetry.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis and structural characterization of the first iron complex derived from the salen-type thymidine-based ligand 1 is reported; the crystal structure of [FeIII(3‘,5‘-bis(salicylaldiminato)-3‘,5‘-dideoxy-β-d-xylo-thymidine)(SCN)] (Fe1) reveals an unusual coordination polymer arranged as a homochiral array of right-handed helices with four-fold screw symmetry.

elements.content:
The stereogenic centers of the nucleoside ligand induce the formation of a homochiral array of helical coordination polymers with a fourfold screw axis.

Helical structures are ubiquitous in nature and of fundamental importance in biological systems. The most prominent examples of natural helices are probably the double-helical B-DNA and the α-helical structure found in proteins. Inspired by the enormous biological relevance of helical structures and their potential applications in the fields of asymmetric catalysis, enantioselective separation, and nonlinear optical materials, the design of artificial polymeric materials exhibiting helical structures has become of great interest. Aside from various types of polymeric organic materials, an increasing number of inorganic coordination compounds showing helical polymeric structures in the solid state have also been reported. Helical coordination compounds can be divided into the classes of helicates (helical complexes of oligomeric ligands and metals) and helical coordination polymers2 (infinite assemblies of organic and metallic tectons in the crystalline phase).
elements.clean_text:
The stereogenic centers of the nucleoside ligand induce the formation of a homochiral array of helical coordination polymers with a fourfold screw axis.



Helical structures are ubiquitous in nature and of fundamental importance in biological systems. The most prominent examples of natural helices are probably the double-helical B-DNA and the α-helical structure found in proteins. Inspired by the enormous biological relevance of helical structures and their potential applications in the fields of asymmetric catalysis, enantioselective separation, and nonlinear optical materials, the design of artificial polymeric materials exhibiting helical structures has become of great interest. Aside from various types of polymeric organic materials, an increasing number of inorganic coordination compounds showing helical polymeric structures in the solid state have also been reported. Helical coordination compounds can be divided into the classes of helicates (helical complexes of oligomeric ligands and metals) and helical coordination polymers2 (infinite assemblies of organic and metallic tectons in the crystalline phase).

elements.content: The most important property of a helix is its chirality. With respect to potential applications such as enantioselective recognition processes, the most challenging task in the synthesis of helical coordination polymers is to yield homochiral products. Usage of achiral building blocks leads either to internal racemates with crystals containing both enantiomers (right-handed P- or left-handed M-helices) or to a racemic conglomerate of homochiral crystals by a spontaneous resolution process. To obtain enantiopure helical products, it is necessary to introduce chiral information into the system, which can be achieved by using chiral and enantiopure ligands.
elements.clean_text: The most important property of a helix is its chirality. With respect to potential applications such as enantioselective recognition processes, the most challenging task in the synthesis of helical coordination polymers is to yield homochiral products. Usage of achiral building blocks leads either to internal racemates with crystals containing both enantiomers (right-handed P- or left-handed M-helices) or to a racemic conglomerate of homochiral crystals by a spontaneous resolution process. To obtain enantiopure helical products, it is necessary to introduce chiral information into the system, which can be achieved by using chiral and enantiopure ligands.

elements.content: The crucial step for the design of helical coordination polymers is the choice of ligands. The ligands should be ditopic and thus capable of bridging metal atoms in certain directions and should also contain steric information that can be interpreted by the arrangement of the bound metal centers, resulting in the formation of helical structures. With respect to these requirements, carbohydrate-based molecules, with their high functionality and availability as well as their several stereogenic centers, represent a promising class of ligands for the synthesis of homochiral coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: The crucial step for the design of helical coordination polymers is the choice of ligands. The ligands should be ditopic and thus capable of bridging metal atoms in certain directions and should also contain steric information that can be interpreted by the arrangement of the bound metal centers, resulting in the formation of helical structures. With respect to these requirements, carbohydrate-based molecules, with their high functionality and availability as well as their several stereogenic centers, represent a promising class of ligands for the synthesis of homochiral coordination polymers.

elements.content: For the present study, we used a thymidine nucleoside derivative as a ditopic ligand. To date, a number of metal complexes of nucleosides and nucleotides have been synthesized and structurally characterized. In most cases, a coordination of the metal ion by the nucleobase or the phosphate residues is observed. Only a few exceptions in which the metal centers are bound to the ribose part of the molecules are known so far. The salen-type ligand 1 (Scheme ) used for this study is based on a 3‘,5‘-diamino-substituted thymidine with xylo-configuration, which was subsequently reacted with salicylaldehyde to yield the corresponding salicylaldiminato-derivative. In this communication, we report the synthesis and solid-state structure of a novel iron(III) complex based on ligand 1.
elements.clean_text: For the present study, we used a thymidine nucleoside derivative as a ditopic ligand. To date, a number of metal complexes of nucleosides and nucleotides have been synthesized and structurally characterized. In most cases, a coordination of the metal ion by the nucleobase or the phosphate residues is observed. Only a few exceptions in which the metal centers are bound to the ribose part of the molecules are known so far. The salen-type ligand 1 (Scheme ) used for this study is based on a 3‘,5‘-diamino-substituted thymidine with xylo-configuration, which was subsequently reacted with salicylaldehyde to yield the corresponding salicylaldiminato-derivative. In this communication, we report the synthesis and solid-state structure of a novel iron(III) complex based on ligand 1.

elements.content: Complex Fe1 was obtained by reacting equimolar amounts of iron(II) perchlorate, ligand 1, and sodium thiocyanate in acetonitrile under aerobic conditions. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of an iron complex of a nucleoside-based ligand containing a 3‘,5‘-N-bis(salicylaldiminato)-2‘,3‘,5‘-trideoxy-nucleoside unit. Crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray structure analysis were obtained by slow evaporation after a few days. The molecular structure of Fe1 is illustrated in Figure . The asymmetric unit contains one complex molecule comprising one iron atom, one ligand molecule, one thiocyanate ion, and two non-coordinated acetonitrile molecules. The iron center is placed in a distorted octahedral coordination environment, assembled by the deprotonated phenolic oxygen atoms O1 and O2, the imino nitrogen atoms N1 and N2, and the nitrogen atom N3 of the thiocyanate ion. The sixth position is occupied by the carbonyl oxygen atom O3a of the pyrimidine base fragment belonging to the neighboring asymmetric unit. The deviation of the observed bond angles from the values expected for an ideal octahedron (90 and 180°) range from 0.9° (N2−Fe−N3) to 17.6° (O2−Fe−N3).
elements.clean_text: Complex Fe1 was obtained by reacting equimolar amounts of iron(II) perchlorate, ligand 1, and sodium thiocyanate in acetonitrile under aerobic conditions. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of an iron complex of a nucleoside-based ligand containing a 3‘,5‘-N-bis(salicylaldiminato)-2‘,3‘,5‘-trideoxy-nucleoside unit. Crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray structure analysis were obtained by slow evaporation after a few days. The molecular structure of Fe1 is illustrated in Figure . The asymmetric unit contains one complex molecule comprising one iron atom, one ligand molecule, one thiocyanate ion, and two non-coordinated acetonitrile molecules. The iron center is placed in a distorted octahedral coordination environment, assembled by the deprotonated phenolic oxygen atoms O1 and O2, the imino nitrogen atoms N1 and N2, and the nitrogen atom N3 of the thiocyanate ion. The sixth position is occupied by the carbonyl oxygen atom O3a of the pyrimidine base fragment belonging to the neighboring asymmetric unit. The deviation of the observed bond angles from the values expected for an ideal octahedron (90 and 180°) range from 0.9° (N2-Fe-N3) to 17.6° (O2-Fe-N3).

elements.content: Molecular structure ofFe1. Thermal ellipsoids are drawn at the 50% probability level. Hydrogen atoms and acetonitrile molecules are omitted for clarity. Bonds drawn as dashed lines indicate symmetry-related complex fragments. Selected bond distances (pm):  Fe−O1 194.1(2), Fe−N1 214.9(3), Fe−O2 191.0(2), Fe−N2 210.4(3), Fe−O3a 218.9(2), Fe−N3 203.9(3). Angles (deg):  O1−Fe−O2 94.59(9), O2−Fe−O3a 81.21(8), O1−Fe−O3a 93.12(8), O2−Fe−N1 105.08(9), O1−Fe−N1 84.93(8), O2−Fe−N2 85.12(9), O1−Fe−N2 168.04(8), O2−Fe−N3 162.45(9), O1−Fe−N3 92.82(10), N1−Fe−N2 83.61(9), O3a−Fe−N1 173.52(9), N1−Fe−N3 91.39(9), O3a−Fe−N2 98.64(8), N2−Fe−N3 90.87(10), O3a−Fe−N3 82.52(9).

Bonds drawn as dashed lines indicate symmetry-related complex fragments. Selected bond distances (pm): Fe-O1 194.1(2), Fe-N1 214.9(3), Fe-O2 191.0(2), Fe-N2 210.4(3), Fe-O3a 218.9(2), Fe-N3 203.9(3). Angles (deg): O1-Fe-O2 94.59(9), O2-Fe-O3a 81.21(8), O1-Fe-O3a 93.12(8), O2-Fe-N1 105.08(9), O1-Fe-N1 84.93(8), O2-Fe-N2 85.12(9), O1-Fe-N2 168.04(8), O2-Fe-N3 162.45(9), O1-Fe-N3 92.82(10), N1-Fe-N2 83.61(9), O3a-Fe-N1 173.52(9), N1-Fe-N3 91.39(9), O3a-Fe-N2 98.64(8), N2-Fe-N3 90.87(10), O3a-Fe-N3 82.52(9).

elements.content: The most striking structural feature of Fe1 is the supramolecular arrangement of the complex units. Because of the coordination of the thymine-carbonyl oxygen O3 to the iron center of the adjacent complex molecule, the complex units are one-dimensionally linked and build up chains in the crystal lattice. In addition to the covalent Fe−O3 bond, the complex molecules within one chain are connected via a hydrogen bond between the protonated N5 atom of the thymine ring and the phenolic O1 atom of the adjacent complex unit (O1···N5 = 270 pm). Because of the absence of further N−H or O−H functions, no hydrogen bonding interactions between the chains are observed in the crystal structure. As an effect of the chirality of the ligand, the chains are formed as exclusively right-handed helices (Figure ), and Fe1 represents one of the relatively rare examples of homochiral coordination polymer arrays in which the chirality is induced by a stereogenic center. In the helices, the complex units are interrelated by a 41 crystallographic screw axis. Therefore, four complex units complete one helical turn (a helical twist of 90°) with a pitch (rise per turn) of 29.2 Å. For comparison, the helical twist in the probably most prominent helical biomolecule B-DNA is 36° per base pair with a pitch of 34 Å. The single helical strands strongly interweave and are oriented in a parallel manner, so the vector between two iron centers at equivalent positions (indicated by the same color in Figure ) in adjacent helices is perpendicular with respect to the helix axis. The complex units are winding around the helix axis in such a way that one phenol ring of each ligand molecule points toward the inside of the helix (illustrated in Figure ). But the aromatic rings are not stacked, as is found in the case of DNA helices, and therefore no π−π stacking contributes to the stabilization of the helical structure in Fe1.
elements.clean_text: The most striking structural feature of Fe1 is the supramolecular arrangement of the complex units. Because of the coordination of the thymine-carbonyl oxygen O3 to the iron center of the adjacent complex molecule, the complex units are one-dimensionally linked and build up chains in the crystal lattice. In addition to the covalent Fe-O3 bond, the complex molecules within one chain are connected via a hydrogen bond between the protonated N5 atom of the thymine ring and the phenolic O1 atom of the adjacent complex unit (O1⋅⋅⋅N5 = 270 pm). Because of the absence of further N-H or O-H functions, no hydrogen bonding interactions between the chains are observed in the crystal structure. As an effect of the chirality of the ligand, the chains are formed as exclusively right-handed helices (Figure ), and Fe1 represents one of the relatively rare examples of homochiral coordination polymer arrays in which the chirality is induced by a stereogenic center. In the helices, the complex units are interrelated by a 41 crystallographic screw axis. Therefore, four complex units complete one helical turn (a helical twist of 90°) with a pitch (rise per turn) of 29.2 Å. For comparison, the helical twist in the probably most prominent helical  biomolecule B-DNA is 36° per base pair with a pitch of 34 Å. The single helical strands strongly interweave and are oriented in a parallel manner, so the vector between two iron centers at equivalent positions (indicated by the same color in Figure ) in adjacent helices is perpendicular with respect to the helix axis. The complex units are winding around the helix axis in such a way that one phenol ring of each ligand molecule points toward the inside of the helix (illustrated in Figure ). But the aromatic rings are not stacked, as is found in the case of DNA helices, and therefore no π-π stacking contributes to the stabilization of the helical structure in Fe1.

elements.content: Two one-stranded, righthanded helices formed byFe1 as space-filling and ball-and-stick models, depicted with unit-cell edges. Four complex units complete one helical turn, equivalent units with respect to translation along the helix axis are presented in the same color.
elements.clean_text: 2  Two one-stranded, righthanded helices formed byFe1 as space-filling and ball-and-stick models, depicted with unit-cell edges. Four complex units complete one helical turn, equivalent units with respect to translation along the helix axis are presented in the same color.

elements.content: The spin and oxidation state of the iron center could be determined by temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements (see Figure S1 of the Supporting Information). The χM T vs T plot is constant over a wide temperature range from 300 K down to about 25 K, indicating an uncoupled paramagnetic system. This is in accordance with the binding situation in Fe1, with large Fe−Fe distances (10.8 Å intrahelical and 9.3 Å or more interhelical) and no direct conjugated bridging units. At low temperatures below 25 K, the χM T curve sharply bends down to lower values, which can be ascribed to a large zero-field splitting. The χM T value of 4.6 K cm3 mol-1 at high temperatures is in good agreement with a spin-only value of 4.38 K cm3 mol-1 for an S = 5/2 system and clearly indicates an iron(III) center with high-spin state in Fe1. The X-band EPR spectra of a powder sample of Fe1 were measured at room temperature and 77 and 3.2 K; the spectra show a single broad signal centered around g = 4.23 that is approximately invariant over the examined temperature range. In the spectrum of a frozen methanolic solution sample at 3.2 K, this signal becomes more defined and an additional small signal appears that is centered around g = 8.81. The spectra can be well-interpreted as those of an iron(III) high-spin species with a strong rhombic distortion and are in good agreement with the magnetic data. Therefore, the complexation of ferrous perchlorate by the ligand 1 under aerobic conditions is accompanied by oxidation, resulting in the ferric high-spin species Fe1.
elements.clean_text: The spin and oxidation state of the iron center could be determined by temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements (see Figure S1 of the Supporting Information). The χM T vs T plot is constant over a wide temperature range from 300 K down to about 25 K, indicating an uncoupled paramagnetic system. This is in accordance with the binding situation in Fe1, with large Fe-Fe distances (10.8 Å intrahelical and 9.3 Å or more interhelical) and no direct conjugated bridging units. At low temperatures below 25 K, the χM T curve sharply bends down to lower values, which can be ascribed to a large zero-field splitting. The χM T value of 4.6 K cm3 mol-1 at high temperatures is in good agreement with a spin-only value of 4.38 K cm3 mol-1 for an S = 5/2 system and clearly indicates an iron(III) center with high-spin state in Fe1. The X-band EPR spectra of a powder sample of Fe1 were measured at room temperature and 77 and 3.2 K; the spectra show a single broad signal centered around g = 4.23 that is approximately invariant over the examined temperature range. In the spectrum of a frozen methanolic solution sample at 3.2 K, this signal becomes more defined and an additional small signal appears that is centered around g = 8.81. The spectra can be well-interpreted as those of an iron(III) high-spin species with a strong rhombic distortion and are in good agreement with the magnetic data. Therefore, the complexation of ferrous perchlorate by the ligand 1 under aerobic conditions is accompanied by oxidation, resulting in the ferric high-spin species Fe1.

elements.content: Keeping in mind that Fe1 is an inorganic coordination compound without biological or catalytical functionality known so far, it is still noteworthy that it resembles some structural features of nucleic acid molecules. First, the ligand of the complex is based on a thymine nucleoside containing a 2-deoxypentose derivative, and Fe1 is the first iron complex of such a nucleoside-based ligand. Second, the complex units are coordinatively linked, forming right-handed helical polymers with a pitch of the same order of magnitude as in B-DNA.
elements.clean_text: Keeping in mind that Fe1 is an inorganic coordination compound without biological or catalytical functionality known so far, it is still noteworthy that it resembles some structural features of nucleic acid molecules. First, the ligand of the complex is based on a thymine nucleoside containing a 2-deoxypentose derivative, and Fe1 is the first iron complex of such a nucleoside-based ligand. Second, the complex units are coordinatively linked, forming right-handed helical polymers with a pitch of the same order of magnitude as in B-DNA.

elements.content: The majority of the recently reported coordination polymer helices align along a twofold 21 screw axis, representing the simplest possible helical arrangement. The assembly of helices of higher symmetries require building blocks with more chiral information and thus a stronger inbuilt directionality in the interaction between the complex units. In the helical polymer Fe1, the chirality is introduced by the nucleoside-based ligand with its three asymmetric centers, resulting in a strong interaction directionality and a four-fold helix symmetry. This is still low in comparison to B-DNA but comparable to the structural motifs of other helical biomolecules such as the α-helix in proteins.
elements.clean_text: The majority of the recently reported coordination polymer helices align along a twofold 21 screw axis, representing the simplest possible helical arrangement. The assembly of helices of higher symmetries require building blocks with more chiral information and thus a stronger inbuilt directionality in the interaction between the complex units. In the helical polymer Fe1, the chirality is introduced by the nucleoside-based ligand with its three asymmetric centers, resulting in a strong interaction directionality and a four-fold helix symmetry. This is still low in comparison to B-DNA but comparable to the structural motifs of other helical biomolecules such as the α-helix in proteins.

elements.content: Fe1 opens a new class of coordination polymers with nucleoside-based salen-type ligands. The donor functions of the nucleobase enables the aggregation of polymeric chains, whereas the chiral enviroment of the binding pocket effects the formation of a helical superstructure. The strong directionality during the polymerization process induced by the multiple stereogenic centers of the saccharide moiety is expressed in the high helical 41 symmetry, compared to the predominant 21 symmetry in other inorganic coordination helices. Taking into account the flexibility of this ligand type with respect to chemical modifications, e.g., introduction of different substituents at the aromatic aldehyde and replacement of the thymine base by other heterocyclic donor groups, the resulting metal complexes represent promising candidates for the synthesis of more coordination polymers with homochiral helicity.
elements.clean_text: Fe1 opens a new class of coordination polymers with nucleoside-based salen-type ligands. The donor functions of the nucleobase enables the aggregation of polymeric chains, whereas the chiral enviroment of the binding pocket effects the formation of a helical superstructure. The strong directionality during the polymerization process induced by the multiple stereogenic centers of the saccharide moiety is expressed in the high helical 41 symmetry, compared to the predominant 21 symmetry in other inorganic coordination helices. Taking into account the flexibility of this ligand type with respect to chemical modifications, e.g., introduction of different substituents at the aromatic aldehyde and replacement of the thymine base by other heterocyclic donor groups, the resulting metal complexes represent promising candidates for the synthesis of more coordination polymers with homochiral helicity.

elements.content: With respect to the potential applications of homochiral helical materials, the synthesis as well as the structural, physical, and chemical examination of further metal complexes containing nucleoside-based salen-type ligands in our laboratories is currently in progress and will be the subject of our ongoing work.
elements.clean_text: With respect to the potential applications of homochiral helical materials, the synthesis as well as the structural, physical, and chemical examination of further metal complexes containing nucleoside-based salen-type ligands in our laboratories is currently in progress and will be the subject of our ongoing work.

elements.content: Experimental details of the X-ray crystallographic studies; magnetic susceptibility data of Fe1; X-ray crystallographic information files (CIF) are available for Fe1. This material can be obtained free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC 602315) via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html or deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.
elements.clean_text:
Supporting Information Available 

Experimental details of the X-ray crystallographic studies; magnetic susceptibility data of Fe1; X-ray crystallographic information files (CIF) are available for Fe1. This material can be obtained free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC 602315) via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html or deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.

cln_elements.content: The spin and oxidation state of the iron center could be determined by temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements (see Figure S1 of the Supporting Information). The χM T vs T plot is constant over a wide temperature range from 300 K down to about 25 K, indicating an uncoupled paramagnetic system. This is in accordance with the binding situation in Fe1, with large Fe−Fe distances (10.8 Å intrahelical and 9.3 Å or more interhelical) and no direct conjugated bridging units. At low temperatures below 25 K, the χM T curve sharply bends down to lower values, which can be ascribed to a large zero-field splitting. The χM T value of 4.6 K cm3 mol-1 at high temperatures is in good agreement with a spin-only value of 4.38 K cm3 mol-1 for an S = 5/2 system and clearly indicates an iron(III) center with high-spin state in Fe1. The X-band EPR spectra of a powder sample of Fe1 were measured at room temperature and 77 and 3.2 K; the spectra show a single broad signal centered around g = 4.23 that is approximately invariant over the examined temperature range. In the spectrum of a frozen methanolic solution sample at 3.2 K, this signal becomes more defined and an additional small signal appears that is centered around g = 8.81. The spectra can be well-interpreted as those of an iron(III) high-spin species with a strong rhombic distortion and are in good agreement with the magnetic data. Therefore, the complexation of ferrous perchlorate by the ligand 1 under aerobic conditions is accompanied by oxidation, resulting in the ferric high-spin species Fe1.

At low temperatures below 25 K, the χM T curve sharply bends down to lower values, which can be ascribed to a large zero-field splitting. The χM T value of 4.6 K cm3 mol-1 at high temperatures is in good agreement with a spin-only value of 4.38 K cm3 mol-1 for an S = 5/2 system and clearly indicates an iron(III) center with high-spin state in Fe1. The X-band EPR spectra of a powder sample of Fe1 were measured at room temperature and 77 and 3.2 K; the spectra show a single broad signal centered around g = 4.23 that is approximately invariant over the examined temperature range. In the spectrum of a frozen methanolic solution sample at 3.2 K, this signal becomes more defined and an additional small signal appears that is centered around g = 8.81. The spectra can be well-interpreted as those of an iron(III) high-spin species with a strong rhombic distortion and are in good agreement with the magnetic data. Therefore, the complexation of ferrous perchlorate by the ligand 1 under aerobic conditions is accompanied by oxidation, resulting in the ferric high-spin species Fe1.

magnetic susceptibility.condition: S = 5/2 system, iron(III) center with high-spin state

peak spectrum.condition: frozen methanolic solution sample at 3.2 K

metadata.title: An Inorganic Thymidine Helix:  Design of Homochiral Helical Arrays
